Clipping: SEWICKLEY WEDDING. A very pleasant occasion was that of the wedding of Mr. Charles F. Nevin to Miss LIzzie Grafton, all of Sewickley, on Thursday evening last. The ceremony took place at the residence of the bride's father, Mr. Grafton, and a large number of invited guests were there to witness the rite and congratulate the handsome couple on their prospect for a long life of wedded happiness. The ceremony was performed by Dr. J.B. Bittinger, of the FIrst Presbyterian church of Sewickley. The usual joyful festivities followed, and with extorted admiration for the splendid display of presents, and the demolition of the good things provided, the evening sped away till "train time" summoned away the party and the guests from the city, and the suburban neighbors hied them home through a sea of mud, to talk over the event of the Sewickley season. Mr. Nevin and his bride started on a tour souithward, whither the kind wishes of all their friends follow them.

chapter.para: Clipping: WHAT'S THAT. Another wedding is on the tapis for this evening, the nuptial vows being taken by Miss Marge Rankin, daughter of Mr. James H. Rankin, and Mr. Robert D. Miller, both members of the oldest families in the Sewickely valley. The ceremony is to be elaborately celebrated in the Sewickley presbyterian church, which today has assumed a decidedly festive appearance for the occasion, the pulpit being fairly lost in a sweet maze of great palms, of ferns clinging about the profuse white chrysanthemums. A large party from the city will be in attendance, for both the young people are very popular here as well in their own town, and have a large circle of relatives. Miss Rankin is a niece of Dr. D.N. Rankin, of Lincoln avenue, and of the late A.J. Rankin, of this city. THrough her mother, who died some years ago, she is related to the Von Bonnhorst family. Mr. Miller is a grandson of the late Rober S. Davis and a nephew of Mrs. L.H. WIllard, of this city. Miss Rankin is a pretty girl and quite young, scarcely having finished her school days. Her bridal robe is a fairy like construction of white silk and billows of chiffon, with orange blossoms in her veil, and a magnificent pendant of pearls and diamonds, an imported jewel the gift of Mr. Miller. Miss Caroline Nevin Rankin, a sister of the bride-elect, is to be maid of honor, preceded by two pretty little flower girls, little Miss Nevin, daughter of Mr. Charles Nevin and little Miss Gormly, daughter of Mr. George Gormly. The maid of honor has a beautiful gown, a Paris affair, it is told. It is fashioned of a lovely net, something quite new here, and has a sort of scintillation of moonlight green through the meshes, draped over white silk. Her bouquet of chrysanthemums is to be tied with long streamers of light green ribbon. The flower girls are to wear pretty frocks of white mull and to carry chrysanthemums. Mr. Walter Miller, brother of the bridegroom-elect, will serve as best man, and the ushers are to be Mr. Swift Miller, Mr. Macon, Mr. Will Chochran, Mr. Robert Nevin, Mr. Harry Atwood and Mr. Will Osburn. No reception follows the church service, the young couple leaving at once for the honeymoon trip, upon the termination of which they will reside on Harry avenue, Sewickley.
